|Ship length={{Convert|152.87|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |Ship beam={{Convert|20.3|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |Ship height= |Ship draught={{Convert|5.4|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |Ship draft= |Ship depth= |Ship hold depth= |Ship decks= |Ship deck clearance= |Ship ramps= |Ship ice class= |Ship power= |Ship propulsion=* 2 × {{Convert|31280|hp|MW|1|abbr=on}} GE/Avio [[LM2500]] gas turbines * 2 × {{Convert|5875|hp|MW|1|abbr=on}} [[SEMT Pielstick]] 12 PA6 STC diesels * 1 × beam propeller * 2 × 4-blade propellers
|Ship speed=*{{Convert|29|kn|lk=in}} *{{Convert|18|kn}} on diesels |Ship range=*{{Convert|7000|nmi|abbr=on}} at {{Convert|18|kn|abbr=on}} *{{Convert|3500|nmi|abbr=on}} at {{Convert|25|kn|abbr=on}} |Ship endurance= |Ship boats=EDO, 20-seat EFRC, Hurricane 733 |Ship capacity=32 passengers or admiral's staff |Ship troops= |Ship complement=*26 officers *110 petty officers *38 sailors |Ship crew= |Ship time to activate= |Ship sensors=* S-1850 LRR tri-dimensional sentry radar with [[Identification friend or foe|IFF]] * ABF TUS 4110 CL hull sonar * Towed linear antenna with Alto torpedo detector
|Ship EW=* Radar jammer * Communication jammer * NGDS system (2 decoy launchers, REM, RIR, LAD) * ''Contralto'' system (2 acoustic decoy launchers) * [[PAAMS]] [[EMPAR]] multifunction radar on G band
|Ship armament=* '''Anti-air;''' * 1 × [[PAAMS]] (48 × [[MBDA Aster|Aster 15 or 30]] anti-air missiles in [[SYLVER launcher|SYLVER]] A50 VLS) * 1 × Sadral launcher with 6 [[Mistral (missile)|Mistral]] missiles<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.alabordache.fr/marine/espacemarine/marine/fregate_rang_1/forbin/presentation.php |title=Caractéristiques Frégate Horizon Forbin|work=alabordache.fr |year=2013 |accessdate=27 March 2013|language=fr}}</ref> on starboard roof of hangar * '''Anti-ship;''' * 8 × [[Exocet]] MM40 Block 3 anti-ship missiles * '''Anti-submarine;''' * 2 × [[MU90 Impact|MU90]] torpedo tubes *'''Guns;''' * 2 × [[Otobreda 76 mm]] super rapid guns * 2 × [[20 mm modèle F2 gun]]
|Ship armour= |Ship aircraft=1 × [[NH90]] helicopter |Ship aircraft facilities= |Ship notes= }} |} '''''Forbin''''' is a large anti-air [[frigate]]<ref>The French Navy traditionally uses "frégate" for all surface combatants smaller than cruisers; the ''Horizon'' class would be considered destroyers by other navies, as reflected in ''Forbin's'' D-prefixed NATO pennant number.</ref> of the [[French Navy]], lead ship of the {{Sclass2-|Horizon|frigate|4}}. Her first task is protecting aircraft carriers, capital ships or civilian ships from supersonic missile attacks; her complement of medium-range anti-air missiles allows her to support the defences of another ship under attack and avoid their saturation. She is also capable of monitoring and controlling operations carried out from the sea by friendly aircraft.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.defense.gouv.fr/marine/decouverte/equipements-moyens-materiel-militaire/batiments-de-combat/fregates/defense-aerienne-type-horizon/forbin-d-620/presentation |title=Forbin (D 620) |work=French Ministry of Defence |year=2013 |accessdate=27 March 2013|language=fr}}</ref> ''Forbin'' is the sixth vessel of the French Navy named after the 17th century admiral [[Claude Forbin-Gardanne]].
== {{anchor|Operations}}Operations== === Building and fitting out === Construction of ''Forbin'' began in [[Lorient]] on 8 April 2002. The hull was built in 14 sections by a variety of subcontractors of DCN, including several companies from Saint-Nazaire. Each section was {{convert|7|m}} high, and {{convert|16|-|20|m}} long. ''Forbin'' was laid down on 16 January 2004; the hull sections were transferred from Saint-Nazaire to Lorient on a barge tugged by ''Alcyon'' and assembled there from February 2004 to January 2005, finishing with the bow. The engines were delivered by [[Avio|FiatAvio]] in September.
''Forbin'' was launched on 10 March 2005, after part of the [[Scorff]] river was dredged to make it deep enough for her draught. She was towed out of her building dock by four tugboats at 16:15, taking advantage of the tide. On 28 October, ''Forbin'' entered dry dock and underwater equipment was installed, notably the sonar, propellers and rudders.
Trials were held throughout 2006. Engine tests started on 10 May, and she sailed for sea trials on 29 June. Tuning of the combat management systems was particularly problematic, setting the completion of the ship off-schedule enough for her commissioning to be delayed by several months. In late January 2007, ''Forbin'' underwent new extensive trials at sea, successfully testing her combat systems in exercises against [[Dassault-Breguet Super Étendard|Super Étendard]] and [[Breguet Atlantic|Atlantique 2]] aircraft. The [[PAAMS]] was tested in late May at the [[Centre d'Essais des Landes]]. From 12 to 17<!-- when?? -->, ''Forbin'' sailed to [[Toulon]], her new home port, where her combat, detection and weapon systems were further finetuned. ''Forbin'' fired an Aster 30 at the test range of the DGA on 25 November.
=== First cruise === ''Forbin'' left Toulon on 3 March 2009 for her first long cruise, visiting [[Morocco]], the [[United States]] and [[Canada]]. She carried a [[Eurocopter AS565|Panther]] from Squadron 36F of the ''[[French Naval Aviation|Aéronavale]]'' to validate her air installations. ''Forbin'' sailed to [[Casablanca]], and then to [[Rio de Janeiro]]. She left Brazil on 30 March, bound for [[Martinique]], where she arrived on 21 April.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://jdb.marine.defense.gouv.fr/index.php/batiment/frb |title=FDA Forbin - Journaux de bord |work=Marine Nationale |year=2013 |accessdate=27 March 2013|language=fr}}</ref> and sailed on to [[Norfolk, Virginia]] and [[New York City|New York]], arriving on 24 April. During the transit, she carried out exercises with {{USS|Forrest Sherman|DDG-98|6}}.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.navy.mil/search/print.asp?story_id=44706&VIRIN=&imagetype=0&page=1 |title=Forrest Sherman Teams with French Ship for PASSEX |first=Adam R. |last=Cole |work=navy.mil |date=25 April 2009 |accessdate=27 March 2013}}</ref> A visit to [[Halifax Regional Municipality|Halifax]] was cancelled. ''Forbin'' was back to France in May, where she took part in the naval parade of 8 May off [[Sainte-Maxime]]. On 25 May, she was at [[Abu Dhabi]]. In June, ''Forbin'' operated with the {{USS|Dwight D. Eisenhower|CVN-69|2}} [[Carrier strike group|carrier group]], supporting "[[Operation Enduring Freedom]]" and maritime security operations.
===Second cruise=== The frigate ''Forbin'' was part of the French naval task group led by the [[aircraft carrier]] {{Ship|French aircraft carrier|Charles de Gaulle|R91|2}} that departed [[Toulon]] on 30 October 2010 for a four-month deployment to the Mediterranean Sea, Red Sea, Indian Ocean. and Persian Gulf.<ref name=defpros>{{cite web | title= Fifth Deployment for French ''Charles de Gaulle'' Aircraft Carrier | url= http://www.defpro.com/news/details/19346/ | work= defpros.news | publisher= Defense Professional | date= November 3, 2010 | accessdate=2010-11-12}}</ref><ref name=Ragahuvanshi>{{cite web | author= Vivek Ragahuvanshi | title= Indo-French Naval Exercises Set To Start | url= http://www.defensenews.com/story.php?i=5390485&c=SEA&s=TOP | publisher= DefenseNews | date= January 6, 2011 | accessdate=2011-01-10}}</ref> The task group commander, Rear Admiral Jean-Louis Kerignard, defined force's mission as follows:
:''The force would help allied navies fight piracy off the coast of Somalia and send jets to support NATO in the skies above Afghanistan.''<ref name=PressTV>{{cite web | title= French warship to join US fleet in PG | url= http://www.presstv.ir/detail/148623.html | work= France | publisher= PressTV | date= October 28, 2010 | accessdate=2010-11-12}}</ref>
Once on station, the ''Charles de Gaulle'' carrier task group joined two [[U.S. Navy]] [[carrier strike group]]s led by the {{Sclass-|Nimitz|aircraft carrier|0}} [[Supercarrier|aircraft carriers]] {{USS|Abraham Lincoln|CVN-72|6}} and {{USS|Harry S. Truman|CVN-75|6}} operating in the Persian Gulf.<ref name=PressTV/> Subsequently, between 7–14 January 2011, the French carrier task group led by ''Charles de Gaulle'' participated with bilateral naval exercise, code named [[Varuna naval exercises|Varuna 10]], with the [[Indian Navy]]. Indian naval units participating in Varuna 10 included the {{Sclass-|Centaur|aircraft carrier}} {{INS|Viraat|R22|2}}, the {{Sclass-|Godavari|frigate}}s {{INS|Godavari|F20|2}} and {{INS|Ganga|F22|2}}; and the {{Sclass-|Shishumar|submarine|4}} [[diesel-electric submarine]] {{INS|Shalki|S46|2}}. Varuna 10 was a two-phase naval exercise, with the harbor phase taking place between 7–11 January and the sea phase between 11–14 January in the [[Arabian Sea]].<ref name=Ragahuvanshi/>
==Gallery== <gallery perrow="3"> Image:Fregate forbin.jpg|Fitting out in Lorient in July 2006 File:Forbin-US Navy film-01.jpg|The [[PAAMS]] of ''Forbin'' Image:Forbin Frigate 01 at the Toulon harbour.jpg|''Forbin'' in Toulon on 29 April 2008 File:Forbin-090606-N-9988F-372.jpg|''Forbin'' with the USS ''Eisenhower'' carrier group File:US Navy 101210-N-8824M-211 The French navy destroyer Forbin (D620), top, the aircraft carrier USS Abraham Lincoln (CVN 72) and the guided-missile d.jpg|With USS ''Abraham Lincoln'' Image:Cheminee tribord du forbin.JPG|Detail of ''Forbin''. The faceted appearance reduces [[radar cross-section]] for [[Stealth ship|stealth]]. File:Plate forme hélicoptère forbin.JPG|Flight deck File:Fregate forbin helicopter hangar.JPG|Flight hangar </gallery>
